title: Simulation workflow
text: main interface running simulations erahumed erahumed_simulation() function: function handles setup execution simulation. Simulation parameters specified via arguments, calling function launches simulation returns fully executed object containing results (note may take time). example runs simulation default model parameters. can customized via arguments erahumed_simulation(). instance: runs simulation modified environmental parameters (fraction organic content suspended solid sediment), : runs simulation different date range. full set simulation parameters documented user manual, well R documentation page ?erahumed_simulation. highlight special parameters: Observational inputs - outflows_df weather_df arguments erahumed_simulation() data-frames containing time-series data serve empirical basis ERAHUMED simulations. details provided user manual. date_start date_end arguments (see ) must fall within time range covered datasets. Rice-field (agrochemical) management system map - rfms_map argument argument primary interface advanced scenario customization, encapsulating full set user-defined agrochemical configurations (including custom chemicals Rice-Field Management Systems, RFMSs). conceptual overview capabilities provided user manual, step--step guide creating custom scenarios available dedicated vignette. Random seed - seed argument controls random number generator used simulation, ensuring reproducible results stochastic elements involved (e.g., random order rice field clusters drained sowing season). Setting fixed value allows obtain identical results re-running simulation; leaving unset may produce slightly different outcomes across runs.
code: sim <- erahumed_simulation() #> Initializing inputs #> Computing hydrology: lake #> Computing hydrology: clusters #> Computing hydrology: ditches #> Computing exposure: clusters #> Computing exposure: ditches #> Computing exposure: lake #> Computing risk: clusters #> Computing risk: ditches #> Computing risk: lake sim #> <ERAHUMED Simulation> #>   Date range             : 2020-01-01 to 2020-12-31  #>   Simulation days        : 366  #>   Clusters               : 552  #>   Management systems     : 2  #>   Chemicals simulated    : 8  #>   Total applications     : 17 #>  #> Need help extracting simulation outputs? Check `?get_results`. sim2 <- erahumed_simulation(foc_ss = 0.20, foc_sed = 0.07) #> Initializing inputs #> Computing hydrology: lake #> Computing hydrology: clusters #> Computing hydrology: ditches #> Computing exposure: clusters #> Computing exposure: ditches #> Computing exposure: lake #> Computing risk: clusters #> Computing risk: ditches #> Computing risk: lake sim2 #> <ERAHUMED Simulation> #>   Date range             : 2020-01-01 to 2020-12-31  #>   Simulation days        : 366  #>   Clusters               : 552  #>   Management systems     : 2  #>   Chemicals simulated    : 8  #>   Total applications     : 17 sim3 <- erahumed_simulation(date_start = "2019-01-01", date_end = "2019-12-31") #> Initializing inputs #> Computing hydrology: lake #> Computing hydrology: clusters #> Computing hydrology: ditches #> Computing exposure: clusters #> Computing exposure: ditches #> Computing exposure: lake #> Computing risk: clusters #> Computing risk: ditches #> Computing risk: lake sim3 #> <ERAHUMED Simulation> #>   Date range             : 2019-01-01 to 2019-12-31  #>   Simulation days        : 365  #>   Clusters               : 552  #>   Management systems     : 2  #>   Chemicals simulated    : 8  #>   Total applications     : 17

title: Simulation workflow
text: Simulation results extracted follows: provided form data.frames, instance: , analysis may proceed way find convenient. instance, chunk create plot water levels whole set rice field clusters, using dplyr ggplot2:
code: lake_hydrology_df <- get_results(sim, component = "hydrology", element = "lake") cluster_hydrology_df <- get_results(sim, component = "hydrology", element = "cluster") cluster_exposure_df <- get_results(sim, component = "exposure", element = "cluster") head(cluster_hydrology_df) #>         date                element_id   area_m2 is_tancat outflow_m3 #> 1 2020-01-01 02_Carrera_del_Saler0-2_0 114881.78      TRUE          0 #> 2 2020-01-01          03_Petxinar0-3_2 116539.90      TRUE          0 #> 3 2020-01-01          03_Petxinar0-3_3 154730.35      TRUE          0 #> 4 2020-01-01          03_Petxinar1-3_1 163789.56      TRUE          0 #> 5 2020-01-01          03_Petxinar1-3_2  83016.51      TRUE          0 #> 6 2020-01-01          03_Petxinar1-3_3 106260.07      TRUE          0 #>   outflow_cm inflow_m3 inflow_cm volume_m3 depth_cm petp_cm #> 1          0  66.63143     0.058  22976.36       20  -0.058 #> 2          0  67.59314     0.058  23307.98       20  -0.058 #> 3          0  89.74360     0.058  30946.07       20  -0.058 #> 4          0  94.99795     0.058  32757.91       20  -0.058 #> 5          0  48.14958     0.058  16603.30       20  -0.058 #> 6          0  61.63084     0.058  21252.01       20  -0.058 library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)  clusters_df <- cluster_hydrology_df  avg_df <- clusters_df |>   group_by(date) |>   summarise(depth_cm = mean(depth_cm))  ggplot() +   geom_line(     data = clusters_df,     mapping = aes(x = date, y = depth_cm, group = element_id),     color = "blue", linewidth = 0.1, alpha = 0.1) +   geom_line(     data = avg_df,      mapping = aes(x = date, y = depth_cm),     color = "black"     ) +   xlab("Date") + ylab("Depth [cm]") +    ggtitle("Cluster simulated water levels")

title: Designing custom agrochemical scenarios
text: begin describing built-definitions objects, way illustrate general concepts. title: Designing custom agrochemical scenarios
text: New chemicals can created chemical() function, example: returns object representing new substance named “X” Toxic Mode Action (TMoA) “Y”, filling unspecified physico-chemical toxicity properties placeholder values. customize properties “X”, specify additional arguments chemical(). instance: sets molecular weight “X” 100g⋅mol−1100\,\text{g}\cdot \text{mol}^{-1}.full list available chemical parameters, see ?chemical relevant sections user manual (example, . Note store object current R session, need assign , example:
code: chemical(display_name = "X", tmoa_id = "Y") #> <erahumed_chemical> #> Name:        X  #> TMoA ID:     Y  #> MW:          330 g/mol #>  #> Physico-chemical properties: #>   Solubility:      500.00 ppm #>   Koc:             200.00 cm³/g #>   Film thickness:  0.200 cm #> Degradation rates: #>   kf (foliage):           0.2000 1/day #>   kw (water column):         0.0500 1/day @ 20.0³C (Q10 = 2.58) #>   ks (saturated sediment):   0.0500 1/day @ 20.0³C (Q10 = 2.58) #>   ks (unsaturated sediment): 0.0500 1/day @ 20.0³C (Q10 = 2.58) #>  #> Toxicity (SSD, log₁₀ scale): #>   Acute   mean ± sd: 7.50 ± 2.50 #>   Chronic mean ± sd: 4.50 ± 2.50 chemical(display_name = "X", tmoa_id = "Y", MW = 100) #> <erahumed_chemical> #> Name:        X  #> TMoA ID:     Y  #> MW:          100 g/mol #>  #> Physico-chemical properties: #>   Solubility:      500.00 ppm #>   Koc:             200.00 cm³/g #>   Film thickness:  0.200 cm #> Degradation rates: #>   kf (foliage):           0.2000 1/day #>   kw (water column):         0.0500 1/day @ 20.0³C (Q10 = 2.58) #>   ks (saturated sediment):   0.0500 1/day @ 20.0³C (Q10 = 2.58) #>   ks (unsaturated sediment): 0.0500 1/day @ 20.0³C (Q10 = 2.58) #>  #> Toxicity (SSD, log₁₀ scale): #>   Acute   mean ± sd: 7.50 ± 2.50 #>   Chronic mean ± sd: 4.50 ± 2.50 chem_x <- chemical(display_name = "X", tmoa_id = "Y", MW = 100)

title: Designing custom agrochemical scenarios
text: creation custom RFMSs proceeds two steps: initialization new_rfms() constructor, application scheduling schedule_application().example, create new RFMS schedules application new compound “X”, proceed follows. first initialize new RFMS, call “Z”: code illustrates, point can also set general properties RFMS, start date sowing season (day year 120 corresponds May 1 regular non-leap year). full list customizable parameters can found ?new_rfms. Subsequently, schedule chemical applications: , chemical argument must valid chemical object, chem_x created . can also built-chemical definition, example: day year applications ideally occur specified seed_day argument, counted sowing day (120 example, chemical “X” scheduled day year 150). actual application days often delayed respect ideal, order satisfy hydrological constraints; described detail user manual. can inspect current definition rfms_z follows: Note RFMS definition incremental: first create empty RFMS object, populate scheduling applications one time. fact, can also use schedule_application() create modified version pre-defined RFMS. instance: Creates new version Clearfield system extra application chemical “X” day 10. practical way code definition custom RFMSs, using R piping syntax, presented last section vignette.
code: rfms_z <- new_rfms(sowing_yday = 120, display_name = "Z") rfms_z <- rfms_z |> schedule_application(chemical = chem_x,                                           seed_day = 30,                                          amount_kg_ha = 1,                                          type = "ground",                                           ) rfms_z <- rfms_z |> schedule_application(chemical = difenoconazole(),                                           seed_day = 80,                                          amount_kg_ha = 0.5,                                          type = "aerial",                                           ) summary(rfms_z) #> <Rice Field Management System> #>   Name               :  Z  #>   Sowing period     : Day 120 to 251  #>   Perelloná period  : Day 306 to 15  #>   Flow height       : 10 cm during sowing season #>   Perelloná height  : 20 cm during Perelloná #>   Applications      : 2 chemical application(s) #>        chemical   type seed_day amount_kg_ha emptying_days #>               X ground       30          1.0             1 #>  Difenoconazole aerial       80          0.5            NA clearfield_bis <- clearfield() |> schedule_application(chemical = chem_x,                                                        seed_day = 10,                                                        amount_kg_ha = 1,                                                        type = "ground"                                                        )

title: Designing custom agrochemical scenarios
text: RFMS map defines RFMSs allocated across rice-field surface Albufera Natural Park. definition also proceeds two steps. First, initialize map choosing default RFMS, can valid RFMS object: allocate portions surface RFMSs using allocate_surface(), example: example, resulting RFMS map 30% Clearfield 70% custom RFMS “Z”: Allocation can also targeted specific types locations rice fields; see ?allocate_surface details.
code: m <- new_rfms_map(default_rfms = rfms_z) m <- m |> allocate_surface(system = clearfield(), target_fraction = 0.3) summary(m) #> <Rice-Field Management System Map Summary> #>   Total clusters        : 552  #>   Management systems: 2  #>         rfms_id assigned_clusters #> 1          1: Z               405 #> 2 2: Clearfield               147

Proceeding bottom-, begin defining substances applied rice fields: (real study, also set specific physico-chemical toxicity properties chemicals. just kept defaults brevity.) full set custom substances, define custom RFMSs — either starting scratch extending existing ones: shown , using R pipe |> syntax convenient defining RFMSs, thanks incremental nature. RFMSs set , allocate new RFMS map: completes round definitions. map object created encodes details relevant agrochemical scenario simulation. can now run simulation scenario passing map object rfms_map argument erahumed_simulation(): point , analysis proceeds usual. details, see main package vignette.
code: chem_1 <- chemical(display_name = "Chem 1", tmoa_id = "TMoA 1") chem_2 <- chemical(display_name = "Chem 2", tmoa_id = "TMoA 1") chem_3 <- chemical(display_name = "Chem 3", tmoa_id = "TMoA 2") rfms_1 <- new_rfms() |>   schedule_application(chem_1, seed_day = 10, amount_kg_ha = 1, type = "ground") |>   schedule_application(chem_2, seed_day = 20, amount_kg_ha = 2, type = "ground") |>   schedule_application(chem_3, seed_day = 70, amount_kg_ha = 2, type = "aerial") |>   schedule_application(difenoconazole(), seed_day = 90, amount_kg_ha = 0.5, type = "aerial")  bomba_bis <- bomba() |>   schedule_application(chem_3, seed_day = 70, amount_kg_ha = 2, type = "aerial") map <- new_rfms_map(default_rfms = rfms_1) |>   allocate_surface(bomba_bis, target_fraction = 0.2) sim <- erahumed_simulation(rfms_map = map) #> Initializing inputs #> Computing hydrology: lake #> Computing hydrology: clusters #> Computing hydrology: ditches #> Computing exposure: clusters #> Computing exposure: ditches #> Computing exposure: lake #> Computing risk: clusters #> Computing risk: ditches #> Computing risk: lake sim #> <ERAHUMED Simulation> #>   Date range             : 2020-01-01 to 2020-12-31  #>   Simulation days        : 366  #>   Clusters               : 552  #>   Management systems     : 2  #>   Chemicals simulated    : 10  #>   Total applications     : 17 #>  #> Need help extracting simulation outputs? title: ERAHUMED Data Analysis and Visualization
text: erahumed R package implements computational engine ERAHUMED Decision Support System, modelling framework assessing hydrology, pesticide fate, ecological risk Albufera Natural Park (València, Spain). integrates models simulate water flows, contaminant transport, biological effects across park’s interconnected water bodies. erahumed, users can: Configure simulations – Define landscape, chemical, management parameters, use built-presets rapid setup. Run model – Execute hydrology, exposure, risk assessment modules reproducible R workflow. Analyse outputs – Retrieve results tidy data.frames, ready statistical analysis visualization. Explore interactively – Launch bundled Shiny application predefined plots, maps, tables model inputs results. package designed research practical decision-making, enabling transparent scenario analysis reproducible environmental assessments. Comprehensive resources available support users different levels: package documentation covers R functions, datasets, Shiny interface bundled erahumed, serving practical reference day--day use. user manual provides -depth description underlying models, algorithms, assumptions. intended researchers wish understand /extend modelling framework. background ERAHUMED project can found main project website.

title: Allocate a Management System to a Surface Fraction — allocate_surface
text: map [erahumed_rfms_map]  cluster map created new_rfms_map() default_rfms_map(). system [erahumed_rfms]  management system assign, created new_rfms() helper functions bomba() clearfield(). target_fraction [numeric(1)]  fraction surface area within selected subset clusters (filtered ditches field_type) allocate given system. Must number 0 1. ditches [integer]  vector ditch IDs (e.g., 1:26) defining subset clusters considered allocation. Defaults ditches. field_type [character(1)]  Type field consider selecting clusters. Must one : "regular" – regular fields "tancat" – tancats "" – field types (default).

title: Allocate a Management System to a Surface Fraction — allocate_surface
text: updated erahumed_rfms_map object new system allocated selected clusters.

title: Allocate a Management System to a Surface Fraction — allocate_surface
text: function allocates management system subset clusters selected based ditches field_type criteria. target_fraction refers fraction total surface area within eligible subset, entire map. Clusters randomly selected eligible subset cumulative surface area selected clusters reaches desired fraction. requested fraction exceeds total available surface subset (e.g., due prior allocations), function issue warning perform partial allocation using remaining candidates. map returned maximum possible surface allocated given constraints.

title: Define a pesticide with physico-chemical and toxicity properties — chemical
text: display_name [character(1)]  common name chemical (e.g., "Acetamiprid"). tmoa_id [character(1)]  Identifier toxic mode action (e.g., "NicotinicAcetylcholine"). MW [numeric(1)]  Molecular weight grams per mole. sol_ppm [numeric(1)]  Water solubility. koc_cm3_g [numeric(1)]  Organic carbon-water partition coefficient (Koc). fet_cm [numeric(1)]  Fraction pesticide washed foliage per cm rainfall. kf_day [numeric(1)]  Degradation rate foliage. kw_day [numeric(1)]  Degradation rate water column. ks_sat_day [numeric(1)]  Degradation rate saturated sediment. ks_unsat_day [numeric(1)]  Degradation rate unsaturated sediment. kw_temp [numeric(1)]  Reference temperature kw (degradation rate water). ks_sat_temp [numeric(1)]  Reference temperature ks_sat (degradation rate saturated sediment). ks_unsat_temp [numeric(1)]  Reference temperature ks_unsat (degradation rate unsaturated sediment). Q10_kw [numeric(1)]  Q10 coefficient temperature correction degradation water. Q10_ks_sat [numeric(1)]  Q10 coefficient temperature correction saturated sediment. Q10_ks_unsat [numeric(1)]  Q10 coefficient temperature correction unsaturated sediment. ssd_acute_mu [numeric(1)]  Mean (log10 scale) acute species sensitivity distribution. unit input (log10(microgram/liter)) interpreted follows: base 10 exponential input median (according acute SSD) concentration micrograms per liter. ssd_acute_sigma [numeric(1)]  Standard deviation (log10 scale) acute species sensitivity distribution. ssd_chronic_mu [numeric(1)]  Mean (log10 scale) chronic species sensitivity distribution.  unit input (log10(microgram/liter)) interpreted follows: base 10 exponential input median (according chronic SSD) concentration micrograms per liter. ssd_chronic_sigma [numeric(1)]  Standard deviation (log10 scale) chronic species sensitivity distribution. pnec_acute_ug_L [numeric(1)]  Predicted Effect Concentration used computation acute risk quotients. pnec_chronic_ug_L [numeric(1)]  Predicted Effect Concentration used computation chronic risk quotients.

title: Initialize an ERAHUMED simulation — erahumed_simulation
code: erahumed_simulation(   date_start = "2020-01-01",   date_end = "2020-12-31",   seed = 840,   outflows_df = erahumed::albufera_outflows,   storage_curve_slope_m2 = 23.66 * 1e+06,   storage_curve_intercept_m3 = 16.75 * 1e+06,   petp_surface_m2 = 53.9 * 1e+06,   weather_df = erahumed::albufera_weather,   ideal_flow_rate_cm = 5,   height_thresh_cm = 0.5,   ditch_level_m = 1,   covmax = 0.5,   jgrow = 152,   dact_m = 0.1,   css_ppm = 50,   foc_ss = 0.1,   foc_sed = 0.05,   bd_g_cm3 = 1.5,   porosity = 0.11,   ksetl_m_day = 2,   rfms_map = default_rfms_map(seed = seed),   .progress = message )

title: Initialize an ERAHUMED simulation — erahumed_simulation
text: date_start [Date(1)]  single-value Date vector (convertible object). Defines starting date date interval simulation. date_end [Date(1)]  single-value Date vector (convertible object). Defines ending date date interval simulation. seed [numeric(1)]  Seed random number generation used simulation algorithms. outflows_df [data.frame]  Time-series dataset provides observational hydrological data Albufera lake, along template albufera_outflows (default value). storage_curve_slope_m2 [numeric(1)]  Slope (linear) storage curve Albufera Lake, square meters. Multiplying value change lake's water level gives corresponding change water volume. default numeric values derived CHJ report Modelo de seguimiento de l’Albufera de Valencia con AQUATOOLDMA. storage_curve_intercept_m3 [numeric(1)]  Intercept linear storage curve Albufera Lake, expressed cubic meters. value represents lake's water volume water level sea level. default numeric values derived CHJ report Modelo de seguimiento de l’Albufera de Valencia con AQUATOOLDMA. petp_surface_m2 [numeric(1)]  surface area (square meters) used convert precipitation evapotranspiration per unit area volume changes Albufera Lake. default numeric value computed package authors corresponds average flooded surface Albufera lake irrigation ditches. weather_df [data.frame]  dataset provides relevant metereological time series, along template albufera_weather (default value). ideal_flow_rate_cm [numeric(1)]  Ideal inflow/outflow cluster, days cluster scheduled flux (.e. simultaneously irrigated drained). Expressed centimeters water depth per day. height_thresh_cm [numeric(1)]  positive number. Height threshold water levels, cluster considered emptied. ditch_level_m [numeric(1)]  Constant water depth ditches. covmax [numeric(1)]  number 0 1. Maximum potential fraction applied chemicals intercepted foliage crop maturation. jgrow [numeric(1)]  positive integer. Length (days) crop maturation cycle rice paddies. dact_m [numeric(1)]  positive number. Active sediment layer depth, "active" refers portion sediment actually involved chemical exchange transport processes. Expressed meters. css_ppm [numeric(1)]  positive number. Concentration water suspended solids, expressed parts per million. foc_ss [numeric(1)]  number 0 1. Fraction organic matter content within suspended solids. foc_sed [numeric(1)]  number 0 1. Fraction organic matter content within sediment. bd_g_cm3 [numeric(1)]  positive number. Bulk density sediment (including solid material pore spaces). Expressed grams per cubic centimeter. porosity [numeric(1)]  number 0 1. fraction total sediment volume occupied pore spaces. ksetl_m_day [numeric(1)]  Settling rate, representing particle-bound transfer sediment. rfms_map [erahumed_rfms_map]  object class rfms_map defines different rice field management systems (RFMSs) assigned spatial clusters within simulation. object also encapsulates full set user-defined agrochemical configurations, including custom chemicals RFMSs, serves main interface scenario customization. See rfms overview RFMS definitions customization options. .progress function used report simulation progress. accept single character string input, representing current stage simulation (e.g., "Computing hydrology: lake"). parameter primarily intended user feedback mechanisms (e.g., console messages). default, prints message R console.

title: Rice Field Management System — rfms
text: functions used define initialize rice field management systems. Specifically: new_rfms() creates empty management system, scheduled chemical applications. jsendra(), bomba(), clearfield() provide predefined systems inspired J. Sendra, Bomba, Clearfield rice varieties, respectively. Additional chemical applications can scheduled using helper function schedule_application(). default values arguments new_rfms() coincide used internally jsendra(), bomba(), clearfield(). detailed explanation RFMS concepts, configuration, built-presets, see RFMS section user manual.

title: Cluster-Based Assignment of Rice-Field Management Systems — rfms_map

title: Cluster-Based Assignment of Rice-Field Management Systems — rfms_map
text: new_rfms_map() initializes cluster map clusters assigned default management system. default_rfms_map() provides predefined map inspired current practices Albufera Natural Park. Specifically, uses J. Sendra system default, allocates small proportions Bomba (10% tancats) Clearfield (10% ditches 1–19). map convenient starting point scenario simulation customization. Cluster assignments can modified using allocate_surface(). detailed explanation RFMS concepts, configuration, spatial allocation, see RFMS section user manual.

title: Schedule chemical application — schedule_application
text: system [erahumed_rfms]  rice field management system application added. See rfms details. chemical [erahumed_chemical]  Chemical compound applied. See chemical details. amount_kg_ha [numeric(1)]  Amount active ingredient applied per hectare. seed_day [integer(1)]  Number days seeding application performed. type [character(1)]  Application method, either 'ground' (requiring draining) 'aerial'. emptying_days [numeric(1)]  Number days field remains empty ground application. chemical always assumed applied last day emptying period. Ignored application type "aerial".

title: erahumed 0.9.0
text: Major improvements ODE solution method underlying CT model component. Physico-chemical processes altogether treated exactly, solving corresponding linear ODE obtained removing terms corresponding outflow, chemical applications solubility (latter processes calculated second stage, masses obtained evolving time step according linear ODE system). Although still suboptimal POV outflow process considered instantaneous simultaneous application (see #146), already gives rise much realistic dynamics, especially relation diffusion process water sediment.
